docs.lead_paragraph: The truth of Christmas is tested in Washington as we move toward a semi-universal health care against the opposition of most Republicans.
docs.snippet: The truth of Christmas is tested in Washington as we move toward a semi-universal health care against the opposition of most Republicans.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy.'' The White House is pushing an independent commission that would make money-saving changes to Medicare as a crucial pillar of President Obama's health care plan. But Mr. Obama's budget director, Peter R. Orszag, hinted on Wednesday that the commission, as proposed in the Senate health bill, would not be tough enough. Under the Senate language, hospitals would be exempt from the commission's cost-cutting powers until 2019. At a breakfast for health care reporters on Wednesday, Mr. Orszag was asked, under those circumstances, just how strong a pillar the independent panel would be.
docs.abstract: White House is pushing for independent Medicare commission that would make money-saving changes as crucial pillar of Pres Obama's health care plan; budget director Peter Orszag hints that commission, as proposed in Senate health bill, would not be tough enough (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: If older Americans think they hear an echo in all the warnings coming out of Washington about frightful cuts to Medicare, they are right. Just 14 months ago, Senator Barack Obama accused his Republican rival in the presidential race, Senator John McCain, of proposing ''drastic cuts to Medicare.'' The Obama campaign asserted that Mr. McCain's health care plan posed a serious risk to Medicare beneficiaries, by proposing savings that would total $882 billion over 10 years and very likely require ''cuts in benefits, eligibility or both.''
docs.abstract: Tables are turned from just 14 months ago, when Senator Barack Obama accused his Republican presidential rival Senator John McCain of proposing drastic cuts to Medicare; Senate Democrats now propose reducing government spending on Medicare by nearly $500 billion over decade to help pay for health care legislation; McCain is attacking Democrats for seeking some of very same Medicare reductions he endorsed during campaign (S)
docs.snippet: If older Americans think they hear an echo in all the warnings coming out of Washington about frightful cuts to Medicare, they are right.      Just 14 months ago, Senator Barack Obama accused his Republican rival in the presidential race, Senator...

docs.lead_paragraph: If America's elderly think there is an eerie echo in all of the warnings in Washington about frightful cuts to Medicare as a result of the Democrats' proposed health care legislation, they are right. They have heard it all before.

docs.lead_paragraph: Thirty-thousand American troops, some of whom sat in the same auditorium with President Obama last night, are now awaiting deployment orders after Mr. Obama announced Tuesday that he plans to send them to fight the growing insurgency in Afghanistan and Pakistan.

headline.main: The Early Word: Selling the Strategy

docs.abstract: As 30,000 troops await their deployment orders, the Obama team fights to convince the nation to support the president's plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: Moments after the Senate cast its final vote on a health care bill before recessing on a recent Saturday evening, Senator Christopher J. Dodd convened an unpublicized meeting of the members of the Senate banking committee.

headline.main: A Study in Contrasts in Financial Overhaul

docs.abstract: Senator Christopher J. Dodd hopes a new plan to forge compromise around legislation overhauling the financial regulatory system will be a turning point in the debate over how Congress and the administration respond to the most severe market crisis in more than 60 years.
